tit.cmt: 統一事項に従ってタイトルに補足説明を加えました。

sen.j: 総髪（そうはつ）は、江戸時代前期から男性神官や儒学者の髪形として結われたもの。
sen.e: Sohatsu is a hairstyle adopted by male Shinto priests and Confucian scholars after the early part of the Edo era.

sen.cmt: ・afterとすると意味が変わってくるのでfromとしました。・統一用語ではEdo era→Edo periodが正です。
sen.e: Sohatsu is a hairstyle adopted by male Shinto priests and Confucian scholars from the early part of the Edo period.

sen.j: 女性の髪の結い方の場合は総髪（そうがみ）と呼ばれる。
sen.e: The hairstyle for females is called Sogami, in spite of using the same kanji characters.
The hairstyle for females is called Sogami, which is written with the same kanji characters as Sohatsu.
sen.cmt: in spite ofでは意味が強すぎるため修正しました。

sen.j: さかやきを剃らずに前髪を後ろに撫で付けて、髪を後ろで引き結ぶか髷を作った形を言う。
sen.e: It is a hairstyle in which the forehead is not shaved into Sakayaki but the bangs are slicked backward, and the hair is tied together in the back or a topknot is made.

sen.e: It is a hairstyle in which the forehead is not shaved and the bangs are slicked backward, and the hair is tied together in the back or a topknot is made.

sen.j: 髪を結ぶ位置が高いものは形がクワイに似ることから「慈姑頭」と呼び、時代劇の医者は大体この髪形をしているが、これはフィクション。
sen.e: The hairstyle in which the hair is tied in a high position is called "Kuwai atama" for the reason that it looks like kuwai (arrowhead), and most doctors selects this hairstyle in jidaigeki (historical plays), which is fictional.

sen.e: The hairstyle in which the hair is tied in a high position is called 'Kuwai atama' for the reason that it looks like kuwai (arrowhead), and most doctors adopt this hairstyle in jidaigeki (historical plays), but this is fictional.

sen.j: 本来、医者は非戦闘員（金創医）として戦場に出るため、誤射を防ぐ目的で髪を剃り上げていたので、江戸の人々は無髪の頭を見れば医者か僧とわかった。
sen.e: Normally doctors, who went to the war fronts as noncombatants ("kinsoi" or surgeons), shaved their head in order to avoid being shot by mistake, so men without a hair were recognized either as a doctor or as a monk in the Edo period.

sen.cmt: soは口語のためhenceに変えました。
sen.e: Normally doctors, who went to the war fronts as noncombatants ("kinsoi" or surgeons), shaved their head in order to avoid being shot by mistake; hence, men without a hair were recognized either as a doctor or as a monk in the Edo period.

sen.j: 僧侶の女犯は罪であったため、不真面目な僧侶などは医者や俳句の師匠の振りをして吉原遊廓に出向きなどもした。
sen.e: As Nyobon (sexual indulgence) is a sin for Buddhist monks, some infidel monks went to play at Yoshihara yukaku (red-light district) pretending to be a doctor or a master of haiku (a Japanese poem in seventeen syllables having a 5-7-5 syllabic form and traditionally containing a reference to the seasons).

sen.j: 髪を残すのはまだ見習いの医者である。
sen.e: Apprentice doctors retained some hair.

sen.j: 神官や儒者は思想上の問題から、戦闘にかかわる意思がないことを誇示するために、武士の印であった月代を剃らないでそのまま髪を残していた。
sen.e: Shinto priests and Confucians, in order to show that they had no intention to fight for ideological reasons, did not make Sakayaki, which was a symbol of samurai (warriors), and retained their hair.

sen.cmt: Sakayakiだけでは通じないため、説明を加えました。
sen.e: Shinto priests and Confucians, in order to show that they had no intention to fight for ideological reasons, did not make Sakayaki (shaved forehead), which was a symbol of samurai (warriors), and retained their hair.

sen.j: また、儒者に限らず他の思想家なども結い、幕末頃には尊皇攘夷思想の若者の間に流行している。
sen.e: Furthermore, not only Confucians but also other thinkers selected this hairstyle, so Sohatsu became fashionable among young people with the thought of Sonno Joi (anti-foreign imperialism) at the end of the Edo period.

sen.e: There remain some pictures and photographs of historical characters, including Shosetsu YUI, Ryoma SAKAMOTO and Isami KONDO, in Sohatsu.
